text:
Q: Having a hard time getting an accurate quotient when running a binary division program A:

it keeps producing a wrong quotient. Can you check what is wrong with my code.

Your input and output routines are fine, but the actual division algorithm is IMO not salvageable.

A trio of solutions

All the following codes will be dividing AL by BL producing a quotient in AL and a remainder in AH.

Using the byte-sized div

Nowhere in your question is there any mention of being restricted to not using the div instruction. So here it is:

  test bl, bl
  jz   @DIV_DIVISION_ERROR
  mov  ah, 0
  div  bl          ; AX / BL  ->  AL is quotient, AH is remainder

Using repeated subtraction

This is by far the simplest of the alternative solutions; (solutions that don't use the div instruction):

  test bl, bl
  jz   @DIV_DIVISION_ERROR
  mov  ah, -1    ; Temporary quotient
.a:
  inc  ah
  sub  al, bl
  jnb  .a
  add  al, bl
  xchg al, ah    ; -> AL is quotient, AH is remainder

Using trial subtraction

A lot faster and probably what you were aiming at, and still not using the div instruction:

  xor  dl, dl    ; Quotient under construction
  mov  cl, 1     ; Nominal weight of the divisor BL
  test bl, bl
  jz   @DIV_DIVISION_ERROR
  js   .Subtract ; Divisor already occupies MSB of its byte-sized container
.ShiftUp:
  shl  cl, 1     ; Adjust the weight of the current divisor
  shl  bl, 1     ; Double the current divisor
  jns  .ShiftUp  ; Until at MSB of the byte-sized container
.Subtract:
  cmp  bl, al    ; Could we borrow-less subtract current divisor from dividend ?
  ja   .Skip     ; No, then skip
  add  dl, cl    ; Add current weight to quotient under construction
  sub  al, bl    ; Lower dividend by current divisor (building remainder)
.Skip:
  shr  bl, 1     ; Try next lower divisor
  shr  cl, 1     ; Adjust to lesser weight
  jnz  .Subtract ; Repeat for as long as there is weight
  mov  ah, al    ; -> AH is remainder
  mov  al, dl    ; -> AL is quotient

Q: SwiftUI turns a String into <uninitialized> when called asynchronously A:

transformEnvironment is marked nonisolated and therefore has to be made "safe".

Your first change should be

.transformEnvironment(\.printer) { @Sendable printer in

That will then provide a warning and more info

**Main actor-isolated property 'print' can not be mutated from a Sendable closure **

Which is resolved by marking Printer Sendable

public struct Printer: Sendable {
    public var print: @Sendable (String) async -> Void = { Swift.print($0) }
}

Q: How do I delete one element from a DataFrame? A:

While modifying entries can be safe, it's specifically unsafe to change the length or ordering of objects you're iterating over because it effectively changes your position in them without notifying the iteration process, leading to errors.. however, if you're streaming the results into some other container (for example reading a list and then just creating a new list How to remove items from a list while iterating?), you can safely make changes!

Given the source is a CSV, consider just fixing the bad line yourself, but for a programmatic or more general approach, you can change rows dynamically, potentially using something like a StringIO to hold the contents before it's converted to a DataFrame if you have sufficient system memory StringIO and pandas read_csv

from io import StringIO
import pandas as pd

with open("some_input.csv") as fh:  # files are iterable by-lines
    with StringIO() as buffer:      # effectively an in-memory file
        for lineno, line in enumerate(fh, 1):  # line numbers generally indexed from 1
            # detect bad lineno or line
            ...

            buffer.write(line)  # should include the newline
        buffer.seek(0)  # rewind the file pointer
        df = pd.read_csv(buffer)

Note that this does require enough system memory to have the contents twice at least briefly! .. if you don't have enough memory, you may need to do something like subclassing open and wrapping its read method, which may be much more involved as you'll have to identify the line yourself amongst fixed-size buffers and likely manage the file pointer so pd.read_csv() stays happy with how much data it receives after each .read() call.. such is the price of saving memory

Q: Which versions of Kotlin are compatible with which versions of Java? A:

The following table shows the Kotlin compiler version that had first started supporting each new JVM target:

Kotlin version Release date JVM targets
1.0 15/2/2016 1.6 only
1.1 7/2/2017 1.6 to 1.8
1.3.30 11/4/2019 1.6 to 12
1.3.70 3/3/2020 1.6 to 13
1.4.0 14/8/2020 1.6 to 14
1.4.20 19/11/2020 1.6 to 15
1.5.0 26/4/2021 1.6 to 16
1.6.0 16/11/2021 1.8 to 17
1.6.20 4/4/2022 1.8 to 18
1.8.0 28/12/2022 1.8 to 19
1.9.0 6/7/2023 1.8 to 20
1.9.20 1/11/2023 1.8 to 21
2.0.0 21/5/2024 1.8 to 22
2.1.0 27/11/2024 1.8 to 23
2.2.0 23/6/2025 1.8 to 24
2.3.0 16/12/2025 1.8 to 25

Q: AI Tools for Java + Spring Boot + Kafka Stack: ChatGPT Pro or Claude Pro? A:

For Java development, Claude Sonnet has worked best for me so far. I’m using it via Cursor, and I can highly recommend this setup because it provides:

  • A built-in IDE experience

  • Strong autocomplete

  • The ability to switch between different models, which makes it easy to compare them and decide which one works best for your workflow

For me, Claude is the best for code generation, and GPT is the best when you need help with documentation.
